column1: The War of the Ring was the great conflict at the end of the Third Age
column2: named for the One Ring and the importance this had in the final outcome. The war was fought between Sauron
column3: the Dark Lord of Mordor who attempted to conquer Middle-earth as he nearly did in the Second Age; and the Free peoples
column4: being a loose alliance of Elves and Men led by the Wise. Saruman was a third power based in Orthanc.

column1: Sauron at all times held the military advantage in the War
column2: due to his overwhelming forces; not only Orcs and Trolls
column3: but Haradrim and the East.  His main objective was to overthrow Gondor
column4: his neighbour and the strongest of his enemies. He had such forces at his command
column5: though
column6: that he was able to fight the war on many fronts
column8: Lonely Mountain and the Elves of Mirkwood in the far north
column9: and Lothlórien from his secondary stronghold at Dol Guldur. There can be no doubt that
column10: had the Wise not achieved and maintained possession of the Ring
column11: Sauron would ultimately have been victorious.

column1: The policy of the Wise was based around the Quest of the Ring: a company of nine under the leadership of Gandalf travelled from Rivendell with the One Ring
column2: with the hope of taking it to Orodruin in Mordor and there destroying it. Because the Ring held much of Saurons native power
column3: they realised that in unmaking it
column4: they would also defeat its creator.

column1: Saruman had claimed alliance with both the Wise and the Dark Lord
column2: but was ultimately fighting for his own ends. In alliance with the Dunlendings
column3: and having Orcs at his own command
column4: his objective was the defeat of Rohan. Until late in the War
column5: he held the advantage
column6: defeating Rohan twice at the Battles of the Fords of Isen.

column1: Sauron had been defeated in the War of the Last Alliance
column2: but because of Isildurs refusal to destroy the One Ring
column3: he was not entirely vanquished.  He survived in spirit form
column4: and the foundations of Barad-dûr were also not destroyed.  Saurons spirit wandered the wastelands of Middle-earth for over 1000 years
column5: but eventually he rebuilt his power and became a threat once again. Around
column6: the Valar sent Maiar Wizards to Middle-earth to help the Free peoples against the growing evil.

column2: Orcs were multiplying and the Witch-king from his fortress in Angmar waged unending war against Arnor. Moria and Minas Ithil fell and were abandoned
column3: among other battles
column4: plagues
column5: and catastrophes which ended the Kingdom of Arnor and the Royal line of Gondor. The evil entity known only as the Necromancer fled from Dol Guldur because of Gandalf
column6: allowing for some centuries of calmness.

column2: Saurons One Ring was found by two of the Stoors in the Gladden River. The Hobbit who got it
column3: under its influence
column4: was corrupted as Gollum and eventually retreated in the Goblin-town under the Misty Mountains. By the end of the Age
column5: Sauron attempted to gather back all the Rings to augment his power. He took the Nine
column6: but of the Seven he managed to reclaim only three
column7: the last of them being the Ring of Thrór"the Nine Sauron has gathered to himself; the Seven also
column8: or else they are destroyed." "You saw the Eye of him that holds the Seven and the Nine."  but could not find the One.

Gandalf was concerned about the weak state of the North. Smaug the Dragons had destroyed both the Kingdom under the Mountain and the town of Dale. About Lonely Mountain was desolation which Sauron might use to regain the northern passes in the mountains and the old lands of Angmar. Gandalf
column2: seeing no hope in Thorins plans of battle and war against Smaug
column3: persuaded him that he should go secretly to Erebor to reclaim its treasure
column4: and to take with him Bilbo Baggins of The Shire.. Smaug was killed by Bard
column5: Erebor was retaken
column7: the kingdoms of Erebor and Dale were re-established. In a small incident along the way
column8: the One Ring was lost by Gollum and wound up in Bilbos hands.

column3: thanks to their efforts

column1: Sauron began reassembling his forces for the final blow against the hated remnants of Númenor and the Eldar. Armies of Easterlings from Khand and beyond the Sea of Rhûn reinforced Mordor
column2: joined by men from South Harad. Orcs
column3: trolls

column4: who learned that the One Ring was in the possession of a "Baggins" in a place called "the Shire". However Sauron was led into thinking that the Shire was on the banks of the Gladden River. Gollum was then set free

column6: who placed him in the care of the Silvan Elves and held him in Mirkwood.

Sauron made an Saurons attack on Osgiliath on Osgiliath on 20 June of  which was the beginning of the War. Sauron saw it as an opportunity to test Denethors strength. Boromir and Faramir managed to defend and destroy the ancient Bridge in order to deny the enemy access to the western side of the river.
About the same time the Elves of Mirkwood were attacked and during the fray
column2: the captive Gollum escaped and would not be found nor by the Elves nor by Saurons servants. The following months
column3: Faramir led several Rangers of Ithilien attacks deep into Mordor-occupied Ithilien
column4: ambushing enemy armies moving to the Black Gate.

column1: The presence of the Nazgûl in the battle of Osgiliath served to make them seem like a military asset against Gondor
column2: concealing from the Wise their true mission
column3: to hunt the Ring. After the assault Sauron sent the Nine unclothed and invisible to search for the Ring under the leadership of the Witch-king. The Ringwraith Khamûl was unable to find the "the Shire" in the vales of Anduin. The Witch-king searched north and west for Gollum or the Shire. Gandalf heard from Radagast about the riders and went to Isengard for counsel
column4: where he was trapped by Saruman.

column1: Saurons plans were halted when he received word of the prophecy in Gondor and the doings of the turncoat Saruman
column2: and concluded that the Wise did not yet have possession of the Ring yet
column3: as he feared. Nazgûl arrived to Isengard around 18 September
column4: but Gandalf had escaped. Traitor Saruman fortified himself in Isengard and convinced the Witch-king that Gandalf alone knew where the Shire and the Ring was
column5: and so the Nine passed into Rohan in search of him. A terrified Gríma answered that Gandalf had passed through Rohan
column7: and even that Saruman had lied to them. The riders were divided into four pairs
column8: and the Witch-King went with the swiftest to Minhiriath.  Along the way they captured several spies of Saruman
column9: and found charts and maps of the Shire.  They sent along the spy to Bree
column10: warning them that they now belonged to Mordor

column1: In 22 September they came to Sarn Ford.  Although the Dúnedain Rangers of the North were guarding the crossing
column2: their chieftain Aragorn was away and the Riders captured the ford
column3: killing many of the Rangers. The Witch-king sent Khamûl and three Riders into the Shire while he went east with the others and then returned to watch the Greenway. A Rider came to Hobbiton at nightfall
column4: but failed to capture Frodo Baggins who departed that same day carrying the Ring to the east. The hunt continued to Buckland and Bree
column5: aided by Saurons spies
column6: such as Bill Ferny and Harry Goatleaf

column1: File:The Lord of the Rings - The Fellowship of the Ring - Council of Elrond.jpg

column2: Frodo came to Rivendell and during his arrival
column3: the Black Riders were temporarily neutralized and the Ringwraiths were forced to return to Mordor to regroup. Some days later
column4: the Council of Elrond was called
column5: where it was decided that the only way to be free of Sauron and the Ring was to cast the Ring into the Cracks of Doom in Mount Doom. Frodo surprised everyone
column7: by declaring that he would take the Ring. The Fellowship_of_the_Ring who would travel to Mordor departed Rivendell in December.

column1: Saruman was caught now between the Wise and Sauron as a known traitor to both. He implemented a strategy of controlling the King of Rohan; sending spies to waylay Frodo Baggins on his flight from the Shire; and dispatching raiding parties on likely routes a Fellowship of the Ring might take the Ring to Gondor. During the fall of the first year of the War
column2: some Ruffians were sent to the Shire to gain control of the region
column3: collecting the crops and suppressing any dissent.

column1: File:The Lord of the Rings - The Two Towers - First Battle of the Fords of Isen.jpg
He then endeavored to kill Théoden Kings Théodred and Éomer and have full control of him. On 25 February
column3: he sent his forces to attack Rohans army (commanded by Théodred and Grimbold) at the Isen. Dunlendings
column4: wolf-riders and Uruk-hai clashed against the Rohirrim in the First Battle of the Fords of Isen with orders to slay Prince Théodred at any cost. Erkenbrand took command of the western defenses of Rohan. He sent a messenger to Edoras to inform the King of the ill news and ask for reinforcements
column5: but Gríma delayed the message. Elfhelm joined Grimbold of Grimslade and were left in charge of the Fords when Erkenbrand tried to send stragglers to Helms Deep. Saruman was successful in eliminating the Prince.

column1: File:Matt Stewart - The Horn of Boromir.jpg - The Horn of Boromir
The 26 February while the Fellowship of the Ring was in the Emyn Muil thinking whether to take the Ring to Minas Tirith or go directly to Mordor
column2: Orcs from Isengard attempted to capture the Ring-bearer; but instead they took Merry and Pippin as prisoners. Éomer hearing of the descent of the Orcband set out from Eastfold against Théodens orders and overtook them outside Fangorn Forest
column3: unknowingly setting the hobbits free.

column1: Having heard the news about Théodreds death
column2: Erkenbrand
column3: who became the commander of Rohans western armies
column4: gathered the forces of Grimbold and Elfhelm to assault Isen once more in the Second Battle of the Fords of Isen (2 March).  Though they had a force of about 2000 men and had constructed a shield wall to hold off the enemy
column5: Sarumans forces overcame them and scattered the retreating Rohirrim across Rohan.

column1: Sarumans victory would not last; he did not know that on the very same day

The next day (3 March) seeking to take the fight away from his people

column4: Gimli and Legolas. On their way they found Ceorl who reported a defeat to the Fords; Théoden then redirected his troops to Helms Deep

column7: until the Deeping Wall was breached and all seemed lost. The surviving horsemen rode out to meet the hordes of Isengard.

column1: Aragorn consulted the Stone of Orthanc and confronted Sauron subduing the stone’s power to his own will. In doing so

column4: however

column1: On 10 March fumes from Mordor veiled the Sun in an attempt by Sauron to disparage or misguide his enemies. The veil blacked out most of Gondor and Rohan who observed that day as The Dawnless Day.

column1: On 15 March three simultaneous battles occurred.

column2: after the enemy passed Osgiliath

Near midnight the Witch-King launched his assault pushing many defenders to the higher levels

As he entered the gate he was confronted by Gandalf who alone stood steadfast. Then a cock crowed and horn from the west sounded. The Witch-King left to deal with the Riders of Rohan at the Rammas Echor. The Battle of the Pelennor Fields began.

column1: A small group of Ruffians was encountered

The Men walked up Bywater Road
column2: to the point where Tolman Cotton Senior was standing and found themselves heavily outnumbered. Their leader fell by arrows as he tried to strike at Merry. The rest surrendered. Pippin had set up a rebellion in Tookland
column3: and returned with one hundred Tooks when the larger group of Men from Waymeet arrived the following day and walked straight into a defensive pocket set up by Merry. Merry and Pippin charged from the eastern bank

column1: After their victory the Hobbits marched on to Bag End

column3: but rather Saruman who revealed that his servant Gríma killed Lotho. Gríma cut Sarumans throat in a rage for years of oppression and abuse

column1: This battle is considered to mark the end of the War.
File:Darrell Sweet - The White Sapling.jpg - The White Sapling
The consequences of the War were "apocalyptical" for the Westlands of Middle-earth. The status quo of many entities were restored
column2: or even radically changed after centuries. Not only the millennia of Saurons dominion were permanently brought to an end
column3: but the relationships of peoples and races were redefined. It is also notable that during the War many personalities died (Denethor
column4: Théoden
column5: Brand
column7: and brought their descendants into the aftermath.

column1: The major effect of the war however was that with the destruction of the One Ring
column2: the Three Rings that had maintained the realms of the Elves in Middle-earth lost their power
column3: and the Elves began to leave for the Undying Lands; significant Elves who marked the history of the Westlands for millennia
column4: like Galadriel and Elrond departed
column5: setting stage for the Dominion of Men.

column1: The downfall of Sauron brought the restoration of the long-awaited line of Kings of Gondor
column2: the restoration of Arnor and simultaneously the Reunited Kingdom of the two kingdoms; after of centuries of nomadic wandering the Rangers of the North had again a kingdom and the Gondorians had a king. This King was Aragorn II a descendant both of Isildur and Anárion; furthermore
column3: his marriage with Arwen reunited the lines of Elrond and Elros since the First Age.

column1: Other political repercussions were the strengthening of the relationships between the Kingdom and Rohan
column2: new relationships with the Ents (who now occupied Treegarth
column3: former Isengard)
column4: the Woses and the Hobbits
column5: now known as free peoples. On the Elven New Year
column6: Celeborn and Thranduil renamed Mirkwood as Eryn Lasgalen and  Celeborn took the southern part below East Bight
column7: naming it East Lórien. The wide forest inbetween was given to the Beornings and the Woodmen.

column1: All the above events made historians to mark the years following the War as the end of the Third Age.
Another calendric change was the New Reckoning which replaced the Stewards Reckoning
column2: and the introduction of Cormarë
column3: a holiday on 25 March that commemorated the fall of Sauron.
